@raphscallion exhaustive down to some depth. Once you restrict your data types to be discriminated unions rather than ints, it gets easier.
@raphscallion yes, and QC2 does that. SmallCheck may be more your style - it exhaustively and predictably tests up to some depth.
.@raphscallion also remember you control the generators. you can quite easily pass in a property and a list of boundary values.
. @raphscallion for simple data, testing deliberately for boundaries makes sense. QC shines when you're testing complex recursive structures
